title: Tuesday, 22nd March, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Welcome

PM

Difficult being jolly, given events in Brussels

11:02 am
PM

Can I just issue a quick warning on stupid Brexit comments -- they will be zapped

PM

I'm sure i dont really have to say this

PM

But given what Ive been reading on the Twitter this morning

11:02 am
PM

Thought it best to

undefined
PM

Now...

11:03 am
PM

I wanted to share a pic of a woman this morning

PM

A particular woman

PM

Karen Byers

11:03 am
PM

Boss of Sports Direct.

PM

But I can't find a pic online anywhere!

PM

So you'll just have to imagine what the female boss of SPD looks like

11:04 am
PM

You didn't know Karen ran the business?

PM

Well, you don't read The Times then

PM

http://www.thetime...c0b18ee0e0715334f0

11:04 am
PM

Fletch has made that free to air

PM

(Fletcher being the Times biz editor)

PM

He's also pulled out a few gems from this Ashley interview

11:05 am
PM

ON his twitter feed

PM

https://twitter.com/fletcherr

PM

You can say thank you by following him

11:05 am
PM

(And then muting him, if you get bored)

PM

Ashley, of course, issued a profit warning through the Times this morning

BE

Yep, it's an extraordinary interview on any number of levels.

11:06 am
Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 389.60, down 34.2 (-8.07%), High: 410.00, Low: 388.30, Volume: 1.07m
PM

Agreed

BE

"We are in trouble, we are not trading very well. We can't make the same profit we made last year," the Sports Direct founder said.

11:06 am
BE

"We are supposed to be taking the profits up, they are not supposed to be coming down, and the more the media frenzy feeds on it, the more it affects us."

BE

Okaaaaaaaaay .............

BE

Let's start with EPS. Sports Direct did 37.86p for YT April 2015

11:07 am
BE

Consensus expects 38p for 2016, 41p for 2017 and 43p for 2018. Or thereabouts.

BE

That's profit going up, not down.

PM

hehehe

11:07 am
BE

Underlying pretax? That goes £300m, £340m, £370m

BE

Underlying Ebitda? That goes £411m, £457m, £495m

BE

Again, up. Not down.

11:07 am
BE

Now, Sports Direct isn't shy about clarifying things.

BE

In the past few months we had a baffling RNS about the role of Michael Murray ... http://www.investe...1601040700126376K/

PM

Baffling being one description

11:08 am
BE

An even more baffling one about its revolver, referring to criticism no one could find: http://www.investe...1602260700082298Q/

BE

A rather perfunctory one about the minimum wage: http://www.investe...1512310700064930K/

BE

And a rather windy one about how they're not running a gulag: http://www.investe...1512180730144971J/

11:09 am
PM

(We should take up Ashley's offer to go and see the non-gulag)

BE

I note the Times was careful to say that "selected press" were invited.

BE

Which I took to mean not us, or the Guardian, or the Mail, or the Telegraph.

11:10 am
BE

So anyway .... when your founder, majority shareholder and .... let's say figurehead boss ... issues a profit warning during a factory tour, doesn't that need a bit of RNS clarification?

PM

Apparently not

BE

There's also the curiosity about the bonus stuff.

11:11 am
BE

The billionaire owner of Newcastle United laid the blame for the "media circus" on Ed Miliband, who, during the election last year, accused Sports Direct of Victorian working practices. Mr Ashley claimed that the former Labour leader had cost Sports Direct and its staff £60 million in lost bonus payouts and said that he would like to "box him [Mr Miliband] in the ears".

BE

"The shares are like wallpaper to me, but for the staff this [the bonus] is lifeworld changing," Mr Ashley said, adding that he wanted to tell MPs: "You are not helping the people who work at Sports Direct — you are hurting them."

BE

Okaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay ....... here are the bonus targets.

11:11 am
BE

Including the 15-16 rebase.

BE

BE

The only way those targets were achievable was international expansion, not domestic sales.

11:12 am
PM

Fair point

BE

But International expansion failed.

PM

And that failure wasnt the Guardian's fault

11:12 am
BE

Indeed. What they bought didn't work, and they didn't find things to buy that would've worked.

BE

All that meant the UK management was hugely overly incentivised to squeeze margin, just to get their "wallpaper".

BE

Resulting in too hard a push on own brands and underinvestment in stores and online.

11:14 am
BE

That's why UK sales have suffered. Not because the Guardian raised the issue of cheap trainers requiring some quite grim working conditions.

BE

I mean .... Primark. A factory making Primark stuff collapsed and killed a bunch of people. Sales didn't suffer at all.

BE

We also get Ashley moaning about having to tell people stuff about the business they own.

11:15 am
BE

We never signed up to this level of exposure. Where in the prospectus does it say we have to do this? Why, if I discover that a six-pair pack of socks sells better than a three-pack, should I tell everyone? Before we floated, I spoke to the big investors, like Andy Brough at Schroders, and I said that I was going to run this business as I had when it was a private company and they said 'yes, stay as you are'. But now it is changing and everyone wants to know everything."

BE

The concern, to be honest, isn't about whether a six-pair pack of socks sells better than a three-pack.

BE

It's that he uses company cash to punt as a quasi retail turnaround incubator

11:16 am
BE

Which wasn't in the prospectus either

BE

Neither was employing the boyfriend of his daughter, unless I missed that bit.

PM

hehehehe

11:17 am
BE

Do I need to continue here?

PM

Go Bryce

PM

No, no that will do

11:17 am
PM

For now

PM

You just helped knock another 2% of the stock

PM

Ashley will be blaming you next

11:18 am
PM

385p live

BE

(@Mo06: any member of the Red Hot Chilli Peppers.)

BE

If Ashley wants me to come to Snarebrook, I will. I'd like to see the factory and listen to him complain about things.

11:19 am
BE

Though I don't expect the invite in the short term.

undefined
PM

Market generally?

11:19 am
PM

Foosie off 25 points i see

PM

Sterling took a hit earlier on the back of the Brussels situation

PM

And the airline / holiday stocks hit -- of course

11:19 am
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 542.00, down 16 (-2.87%), High: 543.50, Low: 526.50, Volume: 7.61m
Tui AG (TUI:LSE): Last: 972.00, down 31 (-3.09%), High: 993.00, Low: 956.50, Volume: 889.90k
Carnival PLC (CCL:LSE): Last: 3,437, down 75 (-2.14%), High: 3,471, Low: 3,392, Volume: 136.67k
11:20 am
Thomas Cook Group plc (TCG:LSE): Last: 87.30, down 5.2 (-5.62%), High: 90.30, Low: 85.35, Volume: 8.18m
PM

Beyond that it's really mixed again

PM

And no i don't know why Allied Minds is top of the 250 board, again

11:21 am
Allied Minds PLC (ALM:LSE): Last: 447.20, up 19.1 (+4.46%), High: 447.20, Low: 417.00, Volume: 21.37k
PM

(cheeckychappy -- taht shouldnt happen on ML... can you screenshot?)

PM

(Ah, no, it is blocked cos of your language. Clean your prose.)

11:22 am
undefined
BE

Right, so Imagination.

BE

The short answer is that we don't know.

11:23 am
BE

Everyone's in no-comment territory.

Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 214.50, up 29.5 (+15.95%), High: 224.25, Low: 186.50, Volume: 5.28m
PM

Sheesh

11:23 am
BE

Following this: http://arstechnica...ation-powervr-gpu/

BE

Apple (AAPL) is in "advanced talks" to acquire British chip design company Imagination Technologies (IMG), according to a source with knowledge of the discussions. When Ars sought comment, Imagination Technologies refused to deny any such planned takeover.

BE

I've no idea whether we should trust Ars Technica's single source with knowledge of the discussions .....

11:24 am
BE

.... though if Ars Technica trusts its single source I'm not sure what those quote marks are doing in the lead.

BE

Anyway, Imagination feltcollaredsource are saying nothing whatsoever.

PM

This is ML

11:25 am
BE

This is sellside, to be clear.

BE

Imagination has announced a substantial restructuring plan which will improve company earnings in FY17 and FY18. Talk of selling the company is, in our view, premature because it would result in a premium on a depressed value of the company
rather than a fair value of a company showing normalized earnings. UK investors have shown themselves eager to sell in the past as well, as was the case with Wolfson Microelectronics which was sold at a premium to an almost trough share price with all accretion from an already known Samsung contract in the Wolfson case accruing to the acquirer. If Apple indeed is the acquirer of Imagination, then it would likely not be interested in the new contracts of Imagination that are to ramp up in end FY17 into FY18 as it would be interested in the technology only. However, Imagination shareholders could forgo considerable part of potential upside from a sale before results of ongoing restructuring and new contracts translating to revenue are seen.

BE

To recap where we are .... Imagination announced a double restructuring in the past month or so.

11:26 am
BE

Cuts £12.5m from the 2017 cost base in March, and £15m from the 2016 cost base announced in February.

PM

(Got to confess I'd never heard of Ars Technica. But they take themselves rather seriously: http://arstechnica.co.uk/about-us/ )

BE

But PowerVR -- the only bit Apple would be interested in, one assumes -- is still recruiting heavily.

11:27 am
BE

Cuts are to he Pure radio business and the SoC design business, neither of which would be any interest to Apple.

BE

And Apple is of course Imagination's fifth-biggest shareholder, having bought the stake as a poison pill back when Intel was also sniffing around.

BE

There's logic, I guess, to Apple taking Imagination in house.

11:28 am
BE

But it's not without problems either. Note that about a quarter of MediaTek chips use IMG cores.

BE

(Though the top end stuff that should be IMG's territory has been moving to Arm's Mali recently.)

BE

Also note that Imagination has a debt covenant test due in April.

11:29 am
BE

Anyway, one assumes Imagination will have to say something. The amount of time it's taken them to say something suggests it will be carefully worded.

PM

ha

PM

yes

11:30 am
BE

And if we have anything else on it before midday, we'll let you know asap.

undefined
PM

Where now?

11:30 am
PM

Kurdistan?

PM

Poor GKP

Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd (GKP:LSE): Last: 7.60, down 0.158 (-2.04%), High: 8.57, Low: 6.75, Volume: 5.57m
11:31 am
PM

As noted, the latest envelope from the Kurdish government is a tad light

PM

http://www.investe...1603221100078960S/

PM

The February payment, which predates the agreement with the KRG's Ministry of Natural Resources ("MNR") of 16 March 2016, is reduced compared to January as a result of the temporary closure of the Kirkuk-Ceyhan export pipeline from 16 February until 11 March.

11:32 am
PM

We noted this last week

BE

Yup, it was known that the pipeline was broken. So the smaller payment shouldn't be a surprise.

BE

GKP's already warned about facing "material uncertainty regarding meeting its debt obligations" so I'm not even sure who's investing in this thing any more.

11:34 am
BE

Here's FirstEnergy from the Genel side of things.

BE

Genel received a total of US$8.3 mm for export payment in February. This includes US$1.4 mm for cost recovery. Gross oil sales from Taq Ta q in February were 62.1 mbbl/d. In a separate statement DNO (DNO NO) received a gross payment for Tawke export of US$13.46 mm including US$2.17 mm for cost oil. This represents US$4.75 mm net to Genel. Tawke deliveries for export in February averaged 66.4 mbbl/d down from an average of 119.4 mbbl/d in January. In addition, Tawke deliveries to the local market in February averaged 6.7 mbbl/d. Market Reaction: Slightly positive. While we appreciate the gross payments have dropped about 23-25% compared to January, the reduction is not as steep as we feared given the context of extended pipeline shutdown and the constrained contribution from fields from Kirkuk operated by NOC. These events could have impacted the amounts that the KRG would have been willing to pay DNO and Genel.

BE

(@nichoman: I can't imagine Genel shareholders would want to wear a 50% discount to the stock's record low to buy a big pile of debt and the licence to a field that's literally rotting through underinvestment.)

11:36 am
undefined
PM

Actually, while on 'gulf' stocks...

Gulfsands Petroleum PLC (GPX:LSE): Last: 12.59, up 4.84 (+62.44%), High: 12.60, Low: 12.26, Volume: 5.53m
11:36 am
PM

This thing is still up despite...

PM

Gulfsands Petroleum Plc (the "Company") notes the recent increase in the Company's share price and confirms that it is not aware of any reason for this movement.

PM

This thing was 3p two weeks ago

11:37 am
PM

Madness

BE

Curious. It feels like there's been an upsurge in boiler room activity recently.

BE

And perhaps an RNS is of limited use, sometimes, if the people getting suckered in don't know about the existence of RNS.

11:40 am
BE

But that's just me waffling. No idea, no evidence, nothing to add.

undefined
BE

Quick line on the banks, I guess.

11:41 am
BE

(@roddy1234: yep. You can take a stroll around a few Regus offices near Moorgate and watch them at work.)

BE

Goldman Sachs says investment banking's an awful business.

BE

1Q is shaping up to be extremely challenging,
with activity across all major revenue areas (ECM,
DCM, trading revenues, IBD, PB) slow. 1Q is
generally the strongest quarter, accounting for
~30% of FY revenues. This “1Q seasonality” does
not appear to be holding in 2016.

11:42 am
BE

Company guidance has started to reflect this with
some banks releasing guidance (BAC: -10%+, Citi:
-15% to -25%, JPM -20% to 25%) and others
commenting on 1Q performance implicitly. We
interpret UBS’ performance comments to imply a
25%-35% decline y/y in IB revenues, while our US
colleagues interpret MS’ guidance as down ~40%
y/y.

BE

Which is rather bad news for Barclays (as well as, one would assume, Goldman).

BE

1Q is historically the strongest quarter of the year
– as such, a “1Q miss” would have a
disproportionate effect on the year as a whole. We
now forecast that European IB revenues, on
aggregate, will decline around 25% y/y. We cut
2016E EPS by 23% for CS, UBS by 14%, DBK by
16% and BARC by 9% (ex the front-loading of runoff
charges).

11:43 am
BE

So Barclays is still a buy. But don't buy quite as enthusiastically, GS advises.

BE

We see meaningful upside to all four European
IBs, which trade in a P/TB range of 0.4x-0.7x for
most (UBS is trading at 1.1x). That said, near-term
headwinds are severe, and we therefore remove
CS from the Conviction List (remains Buy), but
leave BARC as the sole CL Buy IB name in our
coverage. We believe BARC offers comparative
strength ahead of 1Q (due to its macro focus), and
the highest upside (63%) amongst the IB group.
Overall, CL names in our coverage shift toward
national champions in the Eurozone (BNP, SAN),
restructuring (RBS, BARC) and an M&A-exposed
name (BPER).

BE

Here's the chart.

11:45 am
BE

BE

And specific to Barc .............

BE

We believe Barclays’ investment bank, which is more skewed towards FICC Macro businesses (rates and FX) than to equities is better positioned to withstand current revenue headwinds, which we believe are particularly pronounced in ECM/HY underwriting and subsequent secondary trading. However, the group’s higher target capital level announced earlier this month (a longer-term CET1 ratio of 12.7%-13.2%) is a clear setback. We believe the group will be able to meet this target internally by (i) selling
down its 62.3% stake in Barclays Africa to “below 20%” (to enable accounting and regulatory deconsolidation),
(ii) reducing the dividend per share for 2016 and 2017 to 3p (vs. 6.5p in 2015) and (iii) running-down an
additional £8bn of RWAs in non-core (comprising the IB country exits announced in January, Asian Wealth, Southern European credit cards and Egypt, Zimbabwe). In our view, Barclays is pursuing the right strategy in repositioning the group away from the (lower-return) IB, and more towards its (higher-return) UK retail and commercial bank as well as its credit card businesses. We believe that (1) a continued focus on taking out costs, both in the IB and within retail, and (2) successful execution of the accelerated run-down of non-core (Barclays continues to target c.£20bn of RWAs by 2017, despite the £8bn top-up in 1Q16) will be key to restoring group profitability and driving a re-rating of the shares.

11:47 am
BE

There's also an HSBC downgrade of Barclays around, hold to buy.

BE

But I don't have that to hand, so won't share any of it.

BE

Sorry, hold from buy. You know what I meant.

11:47 am
undefined
PM

What do you make of this?

PM

The EU has a corruption problem that could cost it up to €990 billion a year, according to a study commissioned by the European Parliament and released on Monday.

11:48 am
PM

€990bn?

BE

Corruption in what sense?

PM

That article doesnt explain that, helpfully

11:48 am
PM

http://www.politic...udy-fraud-funding/

PM

Ok, here's the actual study

PM

http://www.europar...16%29579319_EN.pdf

11:49 am
PM

Abstract
Corruption is a phenomenon with significant negative consequences for the EU and its
Member States. This research paper uses a mix of methodologies to quantify the overall costs
of corruption in the EU in economic, social and political terms. The findings, based on new
analysis, suggest that corruption costs the EU between €179bn and €990bn in GDP terms on an
annual basis.
Current anti-corruption measures relevant to Member States and the EU as a whole are
described and their effectiveness in reducing the levels of, and opportunities for, corruption
are assessed. Eight potential areas for EU action are identified that might address the barriers
to the effectiveness of current measures. The costs of non-Europe are calculated in relation to
two of these, as well as in relation to the implementation of recently created EU laws.

BE

Wait!

BE

To reduce it, RAND Europe suggested that the EU implement a Union-wide e-procurement system, which would bring down the cost of corruption by an estimated €920 million.

11:50 am
BE

So, a giant Europe-wide IT project to save ~1% of the estimated "corruption" cost.

BE

I can see where this is headed.

PM

hahahaha

11:50 am
PM

Well spotted

BE

Giant IT projects always save you money, right? They never go wrong.

BE

That Politico story is utter waffle. I mean, what on earth am I meant to read into this?

11:52 am
BE

BE

Wut?

PM

To be far, the source doc is probably waffle

11:53 am
PM

100 pages of it

BE

I'm sure something's been lost in either the interpretation or the presentation. But it seems to me, the easiest way to stem unnecessary spending is to not compile overly nebulous 100 page reports.

PM

Actually, flicking through it, the source doc is very detailed

11:54 am
PM

Maybe give em the benefit of the doubt

PM

Rand -- not Politico

BE

(@Airborne: Well put. They're the modern equivalent of the Keynesian ideal of digging a hole then filling it in.)

11:55 am
PM

To be fair again -- i think that e-procurement project cos savings figure related to the E5bn of estimated corruption linked directly to public procurement

PM

But whatever

BE

Yep, whatever.

11:56 am
undefined
PM

Footsie weakened while we've been on air

PM

Off 50 points now

11:57 am
PM

Much of europe off by a similar margin

BE

And it all feels very quiet. Pre-Christmas levels of quiet.

BE

Still no statement from Imagination .....

11:58 am
Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 216.88, up 31.88 (+17.23%), High: 224.25, Low: 186.50, Volume: 6.34m
PM

Nor Sports Direct

BE

Perhaps Imagination's trying not to get boxed in by the Panel by putting something on the record.

11:59 am
BE

We know the company's effectively for sale, and we know that the IP portfolio has plenty of value for certain buyers.

BE

Maybe the Ars Technica story is wrong, or mostly wrong, but sticking out a statement would lock Apple out of the process should one develop.

BE

That's entirely my speculation, to be clear.

12:01 pm
BE

And as CC says, the Panel gives the impression of being more on the side of M&A advisors than investors now.

BE

As in, it's exceptionally difficult to bounce out a statement unless your info is detailed and absolutely undeniable. Bid rumours just don't do it any more, even when correct.

BE

But that's a moan we've had before, and will have again. For today, let's wrap up.

12:03 pm
PM

Yep, we are done

PM

Cheers Rabble

PM

Back tomorrow

12:03 pm
PM

Bye

BE

Though Cazenove, which is Imagination's joint house broker, is making rather cautious noises.
